head.supplied: Question 15: Whether the intellect knows itself by its essence or by something else just as it knows other things

div.p: It is asked whether the intellect knows itself by its essence or by something else just as it knows other things.
It seems that it knows itself by its essence.

Because things that are known by the intellect are known by something other than their essence, such as their species; but what is intelligible, in so far as it is intelligible, is one in species; thus if the intellect were intelligible by something else just as other things, and when the intellect, aside from the fact that it is intelligible, knows, then all other things, aside from the fact that they are intelligible, would also know.

Further, in beings that are separate from matter that which knows and that which is known are the same thing; but the intellect is separate from matter; thus in the intellect the same thing is knowing and known, thus it knows itself by itself.
Further, intelligence and human intellect meet in the genus of intelligible objects; but an intelligence knows itself by its essence; thus the human intellect does too.

Further, the act of knowing arises from the unity of the intelligible and the intellect; but nothing is more united with the intellect than it is with itself; thus it cannot know itself by anything but itself.

Further, the intellect knows itself. Thus it is either by its own essence, by a species, or by its activity; but it is neither by a species nor by its own activity; thus it must be by its own essence. Proof of the assumption: Neither by species, since an intelligible object is abstracted from phantasms, and the intellect does not produce phantasms; nor by its activity, since if it knew its activity, it would know itself by some other activity. Thus that activity either knows or does not know. If it does not know, the same would hold for the first, if it does know, thus it will be by another activity, and in this way it will be possible to proceed in infinity. Further, a particular sense does not sense its activity, thus neither does the intellect know its activity.

The Philosopher says the opposite in the third book of De anima. For he says that
the intellect knows itself just like other things
Arist. DA, III.4 430a2
; but it does not know other things by their essences but by their species; thus the intellect knows itself in the same way.

It must be said that the intellect does not know itself by its essence, and the reason for that is: Nothing is know except in accordance with its actuality, hence nothing is true as something that is available to the cognition of the intellect, except in accordance with its actuality, as the Philosopher says in the ninth book of the Metaphysics.
Indeed, just as sight does not see nor know something potentially coloured but something actually coloured, in the same way does the intellect not know
Arist. Metaph., IX.9 1051a29--31, cf. Auct. Arist. (ed. Hamesse), 6.234.
, and therefore, since matter is being in potentiality, it does not known except through the form by which it is actualized. As a proof of this it must taken into consideration that there is an intellect which is pure and perfect actuality, such as the intellect of God, and it knows itself such that it knows by its essence and all other things by itself; there is another intellect which is in actuality but is not perfect act, such as the intellect of an intelligence, since it knows itself by its essence, but it does not know other things by itself but by their similitudes. But the human intellect is not in actuality by itself, and is therefore called possible, since by itself it is in potentiality, and does therefore not have the cause for its being known from itself. But it does have the cause for its knowing from itself; indeed just as Plato says that
intelligibile objects are separate and that our intellect is intelligible by its participation in those intelligible objects
, it is possible for the Philosopher, when he says that
species are abstracted from intelligible phantasms
De anima III.8 432a8-9 cf. Aquinas, Sent. de anima lib. 3, cap. 7, p. 236, ll. 72--89. See also ibid. lib. 3, cap. 4, p. 218, ll. 8--23 and p. 220, ll. 101--121.
, to say that our intellect is intelligible according to its participation in those species, and he does this in the following way: Since our intellect knows an object by its species, it is able to revert on its own activity, and from the activity it can proceed to its power, and from the power to the essence, and thus by being actualized by another species it can know its own activity, and by the activity it can know itself. Hence that which is first known by a part of the intellect is its actuality, which is its final perfection. Since knowing is not an activity that has an effect outside itself, such as cooling and building, but rather remains in the operating subject, therefore knowing is not a perfection of some external thing like it is the case with building, but is the perfection of the intellect itself.

But this activity can understand in two ways. In one way in the particular, such as when it perceives that it is itself actually knowing, and in another way in the universal, such as when it investigates its own particular activity through its object. And in the same way it can know its own essence in two ways: In one way in the particular, such as when it knows that which it has, such as when Socrates perceives himself having an intellect by the fact that he knows in actuality, and in another way in the universal, such as when it inquires about the nature of the intellect through its activity. And these ways differ, since the presence of the intellect that is actualized in an activity suffices for the first cognition, but for the second cognition a subtle and distinguishing inquisition is required, and for this reason many are ignorant about the nature of the intellect and many are wrong about it.

To the first argument it must be said that the intellect and that which is known are the same in actuality, and not intellect and that which is known in potentiality. Now, the intelligible species is the immediate principle of knowledge. Hence wherever there is a intelligible species in actuality, it can know, but whichever species that is in the stone or in a material thing outside the intellect is only intelligible in potency, and therefore no intelligible thing outside our intellect has its immediate principle of knowledge in itself, and for that reason cannot know. But a species which is in the intellect is intelligible in actuality, and therefore, since our intellect has its immediate principle of knowledge in itself, it can know aside from the fact that it is intelligible, and it is not in this way in other things.

To the second argument it must be said that these things are said to be separate from matter which are known in actuality. Hence,
the Philosopher says in the third book of De anima
exactly in the same way as things are separable from matter so it is the case for the intellect
Arist. De anima III.4 429b21--2
, but that which is known in actuality and the intellect are the same, just as that which is perceptible in actuality and the sense. For certainly the perceptible in actuality and sense are not the same except because the same form belongs to both, since the species which is caused by something perceptible, as by an agent, is in the sense as in a subject, and in the same way in the proposition: That which is known in actuality and the intellect are said to be the same, because the species of that which is known in actuality is the realizing form which informs the intellect, and by this form the intellect knows by traversion over itself and not by its essence.

To the third argument it must be said that the intellect of the intelligence is perfect actuality because it always is actualized. For in itself is has connate species. But in itself our intellect is in potentiality as possible, and the agent intellect itself, insofar as it is actualized, is the actualization of the intelligible things, and not known before it knows.

To the fourth it must be said that the act of knowing is caused by the union of the object and the intellect, but although nothing is more united with the intellect than it is with itself, it still cannot be united with itself as an object, because the object of our intellect is the nature of a thing which is outside the soul, and that cannot be united with the intellect except by a species.

To the final argument it must be said that it knows itself both by a species and by an activity, but not by its own species, which the argument proves, but by a species which belongs to something else. Similarly it knows itself by its own activity, and it knows that activity by still another activity. Therefore it must be understood that there is an intellect which is its own knowing, and therefore it knows its own essence and own knowing by a unitary activity, since they are the same, as the intellect of God. And there is another intellect which is not its own knowing, but by its essence it is object of its own knowing, such as the intellect of an intelligence, and although its knowing and its essence differ, it still knows its own essence and own knowing by a unitary act, since knowing is the perfection of its essence, and a thing and its perfection are known by a unitary act. But the human intellect is neither its own knowing nor is its essence object of its own knowing, and therefore it cannot know the object and its own knowing by a unitary act, because its knowing is not the perfection of its object. For knowing the stone is not the perfection of the stone, but it is the perfection of the intellect, and therefore it is not possible to know the stone and the knowing itself by a unitary act. Hence by this it must be said to the argument that it knows its own activity and its object by a different activity, and it knows that activity in actuality, and thus infinitely, and it is not inconvenient to proceed infinitely in activities of the intellect and reason.

To the second proof it must be said that a sense senses by an alteration of a corporeal organ, and nothing corporeal alters itself, and therefore the sense is not altered except by something external. But the intellect is not altered by the alteration of the corporeal organ, but spiritually, and something spiritual can easily turn itself on itself, and therefore Plato said that the first mover moves itself, since the first mover could be soul and its activities, just as to love and cherish, and in this way it could be its movement.
